column4: Flood risk is calculated in a monte-carlo framework under different RCP projection scenarios. They look at income loss due to average annual cloastal flood damage as a function of income bracket across 3 different areas (county, redwood shores and east palo alto). The areas have different demographics, and east palo alto and redwood shores are neighborhoods in the county. The risk data is at the household level and the income data is from ACS downscaled to the home, but the comparisons appear to be at the neighborhood level and across income (homes within the areas) so breaking this into two measurements

column11: Operationalize fairness through aggregation functions that represent what the motivating moral principles say about fairness. Optimal values are defined within each ethical framework, not across them. All benefits are calculated based on exogenous, hypothetical adaptation strategies. The reason this utilitarian framework is distinct from something in Kind et al., (2020) is that the authors roughly make the claim here that more overall utility is one conception of fairness. That distributive framing is missing in most social welfare function literature.

column11: They see examine how CRS participation affects distribution of income in census tracts. They control for losses and exposure, and they control for what others call vulnerability indicators but they don't use that framing. They address concerns about simultaneity bias, so the treatment is potentially exogenous. They don't examine some of the procedural reasons that participation in tracts with high poverty rates is low (capacity, barriers to application, having the requirements in place to be eligible to submit a CRS application is costly and requires expertise) and it's not clear if the comparison across CRS vs. not tracts is all-else-equal

column11: This seems like recognition because they are looking at outcomes on resettlement based on presumed racialized preferences for residential choice after buyouts. They don't do a counterfactual for how resettlement after buyouts contrasts to general resettlement outside the context of buyouts. They argue that it's the fact normal market forces are working within the "technocractic" context of buyouts that raises equity implications, but what those are isn't clear (meaning, what would be more fair and how does the measurement correspond to that) so not assigning distributive

column4: Distance resettled after buyout
column9: Exposure and adaptation cost as a means at getting at recognition considerations
column11: The key fairness frame they provide is "place-based inequities mean that the federal government’s seemingly fair and rational policy of managed retreat can end up playing out quite differently when equally applied to different types of flood-prone neighborhoods" They provide typologies of retreat & relocation based on "social values of homes", which calls to the intrinsic value of communities. This seems like it fits best in a recognition lens. They show typologies of buyout programs, with collective retreat being the type that best maintains community attachments and social value of home. This is a typology their measurement suggests is available to the most privileged (white & wealthier), indicating neighborhood inequities in the resettlement they evaluated
